awd_titl_txt: Workshops for Faculty and Staff Development in Implementing Physics Advanced Laboratory Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by conducting a series of workshops to enable physics faculty and staff members to adopt improved experiments in their undergraduate advanced laboratories. These faculty and staff members are often assigned to teach these advanced laboratory courses in areas beyond their own research specialty. The instructors often lack the expertise to understand the background of the labs, design the labs, or best integrate the labs with other instruction. This project is especially important for instructors in small schools who often lack access to the facilities and expertise found in larger institutions. The project will create a mobile workshop capable of bringing workshops to these locations as well.

Previous workshops included quantum mechanics experiments with photons, nuclear magnetic resonance, quantum analogs, Hall effect, gravitational wave interferometry, graphene, high Tc superconductivity, using field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), and open cavity helium neon laser experiments. The topics for the workshops supported by this award will be governed by demand and will include newly developed upper division laboratory experiments.  The effectiveness of the workshops will be evaluated by questionnaires distributed to the participants and mentors immediately after the workshops. There will also be a follow-up survey sent to the participants 1.5 years after the workshops. The questions will deal with the content and value of the workshops, if the participants implemented the featured experiment at their home institutions, and what was required to do so. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Engaged Student Learning track, the program supports the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION OF PHYSICS TEACHERS, INCORPORATED

por.por_cntn:
An important aspect of an undergraduate degree in physics is the experience students get with hands-on laboratory work.  This includes laboratory work beyond the introductory courses which includes topics from all areas of experimental physics.  Typically, there are only a small (1-2) number of faculty in each department who teach these types of courses.   In addition, these courses cover a broad array of topics, so the faculty and staff who teach them are nearly always required to lead students who are doing experiments far outside the instructor's area of specialization.  This makes it challenging for faculty to incorporate new, modern experiments into their curriculum.

The Advanced Laboratory Physics Association (ALPhA) created the Laboratory Immersions program in 2010 to help address the difficulties faced by these instructors.  At an Immersion, typically 2-3 days in length, faculty work through an experiment just as their students would, under the guidance of a faculty mentor who teaches that experiment themselves.  This expert help provides faculty with the experience they need to develop the same experiment at their institution.

This program has attracted participants from over 40% of the physics departments in the United States, with 471 unique individuals attending Immersions.  Faculty find the program to be highly valuable, and 30% have returned to take additional Immersions.   The participants have come from nearly all states in the U.S.

The most important success of the Immersions is that a very large fraction of the participants implement what they learn at the Immersion at their own institution.  The program has reached a large fraction of the departments in the U.S., and those departments tend to graduate the most physics students.  In addition, with these faculty interacting with a large fraction of physics majors at their schools, the Immersions program has been able to impact a significant number of the physics students in the country.

The partial National Science Foundation (NSF) support for this program, carefully managed, has allowed the program to flourish to the point where it has now become sustainable.  The Jonathan F. Reichert Foundation has partnered with Synopsys to create an endowed fund that will support the ALPhA Immersions indefinitely.  This project is an excellent example of how NSF can provide support over time to allow quality programs to grow and attract additional private support.
